natural problem: How many increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20?
natural solution: List the primes up to 20 (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19) and note that the largest possible prime in the sum is 13 because no two primes add up to $20-17=3$ and of course 19 is too large as well. Also, observe that 2, the only even prime, must be in the sum, because the sum of three odd primes can never be 20.

Starting with 2 and 3, we see that $20-(2+3)=15$ is not prime. Next, 2 and 5 give $20-(2+5)=13$, a prime, so one such increasing sequence is 2, 5, 13. Next, we take 2 and 7, and we see that $20-(2+7)=11$ is prime as well, giving us the second sequence 2, 7, 11.
11 and 13 are already included, so we are done.
Thus, there are $\boxed{2}$ increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers that have a sum of 20.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> l. f l = (length l = 3 \<and> (\<forall> i < length l - 1. l ! i < l ! (i + 1)) \<and> (\<forall> i < length l. prime (l ! i)) \<and> sum_list l = 20)"
shows  "card {l. f l} = 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 List the primes up to 20 (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19) and note that the largest possible prime in the sum is 13 because no two primes add up to $20-17=3$ and of course 19 is too large as well. Also, observe that 2, the only even prime, must be in the sum, because the sum of three odd primes can never be 20.
 Starting with 2 and 3, we see that $20-(2+3)=15$ is not prime. Next, 2 and 5 give $20-(2+5)=13$, a prime, so one such increasing sequence is 2, 5, 13. Next, we take 2 and 7, and we see that $20-(2+7)=11$ is prime as well, giving us the second sequence 2, 7, 11.
 11 and 13 are already included, so we are done.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{2}$ increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers that have a sum of 20.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> l. f l = (length l = 3 \<and> (\<forall> i < length l - 1. l ! i < l ! (i + 1)) \<and> (\<forall> i < length l. prime (l ! i)) \<and> sum_list l = 20)"
shows  "card {l. f l} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many lists of three natural numbers are there such that each number in the list is prime, each number is larger than the previous one, and the sum of the numbers in the list is 20? The final answer is 2.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes seq :: "(nat * nat * nat) set"
assumes h0 : "seq = {(p, q, r). prime p \<and> prime q \<and> prime r \<and> p < q \<and> q < r \<and> p + q + r = 20}"
shows  "card seq = 2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 List the primes up to 20 (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19) and note that the largest possible prime in the sum is 13 because no two primes add up to $20-17=3$ and of course 19 is too large as well. Also, observe that 2, the only even prime, must be in the sum, because the sum of three odd primes can never be 20.
 Starting with 2 and 3, we see that $20-(2+3)=15$ is not prime. Next, 2 and 5 give $20-(2+5)=13$, a prime, so one such increasing sequence is 2, 5, 13. Next, we take 2 and 7, and we see that $20-(2+7)=11$ is prime as well, giving us the second sequence 2, 7, 11.
 11 and 13 are already included, so we are done.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{2}$ increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers that have a sum of 20.
 *)

theorem
fixes seq :: "(nat * nat * nat) set"
assumes h0 : "seq = {(p, q, r). prime p \<and> prime q \<and> prime r \<and> p < q \<and> q < r \<and> p + q + r = 20}"
shows  "card seq = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: "How many sets of three distinct prime numbers are there such that the sum of the numbers is 20? The final answer is 2."

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes seq :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length seq = 3"
and h1 : "distinct seq"
and h2 : "sum_list seq = 20"
and h3 : "\<forall> n \<in> set seq. is_prime n"
and h4 : "sorted seq"
shows  "card {seq. length seq = 3 \<and> distinct seq \<and> sum_list seq = 20 \<and> (\<forall> n \<in> set seq. is_prime n) \<and> sorted seq} = 2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 List the primes up to 20 (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19) and note that the largest possible prime in the sum is 13 because no two primes add up to $20-17=3$ and of course 19 is too large as well. Also, observe that 2, the only even prime, must be in the sum, because the sum of three odd primes can never be 20.
 Starting with 2 and 3, we see that $20-(2+3)=15$ is not prime. Next, 2 and 5 give $20-(2+5)=13$, a prime, so one such increasing sequence is 2, 5, 13. Next, we take 2 and 7, and we see that $20-(2+7)=11$ is prime as well, giving us the second sequence 2, 7, 11.
 11 and 13 are already included, so we are done.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{2}$ increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers that have a sum of 20.
 *)

theorem
fixes seq :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length seq = 3"
and h1 : "distinct seq"
and h2 : "sum_list seq = 20"
and h3 : "\<forall> n \<in> set seq. is_prime n"
and h4 : "sorted seq"
shows  "card {seq. length seq = 3 \<and> distinct seq \<and> sum_list seq = 20 \<and> (\<forall> n \<in> set seq. is_prime n) \<and> sorted seq} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: How many different ordered lists of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final answer is 2.

theorem
fixes prime_triples :: "(nat * nat * nat) set"
assumes h0 : "prime_triples = {(p, q, r). prime p \<and> prime q \<and> prime r \<and> p < q < r \<and> p + q + r = 20}"
shows  "card prime_triples = 2"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 List the primes up to 20 (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19) and note that the largest possible prime in the sum is 13 because no two primes add up to $20-17=3$ and of course 19 is too large as well. Also, observe that 2, the only even prime, must be in the sum, because the sum of three odd primes can never be 20.

theorem
fixes prime_triples :: "(nat * nat * nat) set"
assumes h0 : "prime_triples = {(p, q, r). prime p \<and> prime q \<and> prime r \<and> p < q < r \<and> p + q + r = 20}"

a_3.informal problem: How many triplets of prime numbers (p, q, r) are there such that p, q, and r are distinct, arranged in ascending order, and their sum equals 20? The final answer is 2.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool" and sequence :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n \<longleftrightarrow> (n > 1 \<and> (\<forall> m. m > 1 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. sequence n = (if n = 1 then 2 else if n = 2 then 3 else if n = 3 then 5 else if n = 4 then 7 else if n = 5 then 11 else if n = 6 then 13 else if n = 7 then 17 else if n = 8 then 19 else if n = 9 then 23 else 0)"
and h2 : "\<exists> x y z. x < y \<and> y < z \<and> prime x \<and> prime y \<and> prime z \<and> x + y + z = 20"
shows  "card { (x, y, z). x < y \<and> y < z \<and> prime x \<and> prime y \<and> prime z \<and> x + y + z = 20 } = 2"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 List the primes up to 20 (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19) and note that the largest possible prime in the sum is 13 because no two primes add up to $20-17=3$ and of course 19 is too large as well. Also, observe that 2, the only even prime, must be in the sum, because the sum of three odd primes can never be 20.
 Starting with 2 and 3, we see that $20-(2+3)=15$ is not prime. Next, 2 and 5 give $20-(2+5)=13$, a prime, so one such increasing sequence is 2, 5, 13. Next, we take 2 and 7, and we see that $20-(2+7)=11$ is prime as well, giving us the second sequence 2, 7, 11.
 11 and 13 are already included, so we are done.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{2}$ increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers that have a sum of 20.
 *)

theorem
fixes prime :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool" and sequence :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. prime n \<longleftrightarrow> (n > 1 \<and> (\<forall> m. m > 1 \<and> m < n \<longrightarrow> n mod m \<noteq> 0))"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. sequence n = (if n = 1 then 2 else if n = 2 then 3 else if n = 3 then 5 else if n = 4 then 7 else if n = 5 then 11 else if n = 6 then 13 else if n = 7 then 17 else if n = 8 then 19 else if n = 9 then 23 else 0)"
and h2 : "\<exists> x y z. x < y \<and> y < z \<and> prime x \<and> prime y \<and> prime z \<and> x + y + z = 20"
shows  "card { (x, y, z). x < y \<and> y < z \<and> prime x \<and> prime y \<and> prime z \<and> x + y + z = 20 } = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A prime number is defined as an integer greater than 1 that has no divisors other than 1 and itself. We have a sequence where the first nine numbers are 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, and after that the sequence is zero. Find how many distinct sets of three prime numbers from this sequence can be added up to get 20. The final answer is 2.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes seq :: "(nat list) \<Rightarrow> bool" and count :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "seq = (\<lambda>l. length l = 3 \<and> distinct l \<and> (\<forall>i \<in> set l. prime i) \<and> sum id set l = 20)"
and h1 : "count = card {l. seq l}"
shows  "count = 2"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 List the primes up to 20 (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19) and note that the largest possible prime in the sum is 13 because no two primes add up to $20-17=3$ and of course 19 is too large as well. Also, observe that 2, the only even prime, must be in the sum, because the sum of three odd primes can never be 20.
 Starting with 2 and 3, we see that $20-(2+3)=15$ is not prime. Next, 2 and 5 give $20-(2+5)=13$, a prime, so one such increasing sequence is 2, 5, 13. Next, we take 2 and 7, and we see that $20-(2+7)=11$ is prime as well, giving us the second sequence 2, 7, 11.
 11 and 13 are already included, so we are done.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{2}$ increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers that have a sum of 20.
 *)

theorem
fixes seq :: "(nat list) \<Rightarrow> bool" and count :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "seq = (\<lambda>l. length l = 3 \<and> distinct l \<and> (\<forall>i \<in> set l. prime i) \<and> sum id set l = 20)"
and h1 : "count = card {l. seq l}"
shows  "count = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: How many distinct sequences of three prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final answer is 2.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prime_sequence :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length prime_sequence = 3"
and h1 : "distinct prime_sequence"
and h2 : "sum_list prime_sequence = 20"
and h3 : "sorted prime_sequence"
and h4 : "all is_prime prime_sequence"
shows  "card {prime_sequence} = 2"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 List the primes up to 20 (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19) and note that the largest possible prime in the sum is 13 because no two primes add up to $20-17=3$ and of course 19 is too large as well. Also, observe that 2, the only even prime, must be in the sum, because the sum of three odd primes can never be 20.

 11 and 13 are already included, so we are done.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{2}$ increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers that have a sum of 20.
 *)

theorem
fixes prime_sequence :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length prime_sequence = 3"
and h1 : "distinct prime_sequence"
and h2 : "sum_list prime_sequence = 20"
and h3 : "sorted prime_sequence"
and h4 : "all is_prime prime_sequence"
shows  "card {prime_sequence} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the number of distinct sequences of three different prime numbers that sum to 20 and are sorted in ascending order. The final answer is 2.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a < b"
and h1 : "b < c"
and h2 : "is_prime a"
and h3 : "is_prime b"
and h4 : "is_prime c"
shows  "card {(a, b, c) | a b c. a + b + c = 20} = 2"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 List the primes up to 20 (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19) and note that the largest possible prime in the sum is 13 because no two primes add up to $20-17=3$ and of course 19 is too large as well. Also, observe that 2, the only even prime, must be in the sum, because the sum of three odd primes can never be 20.
 Starting with 2 and 3, we see that $20-(2+3)=15$ is not prime. Next, 2 and 5 give $20-(2+5)=13$, a prime, so one such increasing sequence is 2, 5, 13. Next, we take 2 and 7, and we see that $20-(2+7)=11$ is prime as well, giving us the second sequence 2, 7, 11.
 11 and 13 are already included, so we are done.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{2}$ increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers that have a sum of 20.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a < b"
and h1 : "b < c"
and h2 : "is_prime a"
and h3 : "is_prime b"
and h4 : "is_prime c"
shows  "card {(a, b, c) | a b c. a + b + c = 20} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find two distinct sets of three prime numbers $(a, b, c)$ such that $a < b < c$ and $a + b + c = 20$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> l. f l = (length l = 3 \<and> distinct l \<and> (\<forall> x \<in> set l. prime x) \<and> sum_list l = 20)"
shows  "card {l. f l} = 2"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers have a sum of 20? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 List the primes up to 20 (2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19) and note that the largest possible prime in the sum is 13 because no two primes add up to $20-17=3$ and of course 19 is too large as well. Also, observe that 2, the only even prime, must be in the sum, because the sum of three odd primes can never be 20.

 11 and 13 are already included, so we are done.
 Thus, there are $\boxed{2}$ increasing sequences of three distinct prime numbers that have a sum of 20.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat list \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> l. f l = (length l = 3 \<and> distinct l \<and> (\<forall> x \<in> set l. prime x) \<and> sum_list l = 20)"
shows  "card {l. f l} = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: "How many distinct lists of three prime numbers have a sum of 20? The answer is 2."

fixes sequences :: "(nat list) set"
assumes h0 : "sequences = {s. length s = 3 \<and> distinct s \<and> all is_prime s \<and> sum_list s = 20}"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
